question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering the factors mentioned, there seems to be a plausible basis for expecting that Trump could gain more votes among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden compared to a generic Democrat, due to Biden's apparent disadvantage in public opinion polls and the specificity of the candidate influencing respondent preferences. However, predicting the exact margin of this difference involves uncertainty, particularly regarding how closely Manifold respondents mirror the general public's preferences and how their perceptions of Biden specifically might influence their voting choices.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the current situation, there are already signs of discontent among some Democratic Party members with two safe-seat members publicly urging Biden to drop out and two endangered Democrats expressing their doubts about his chances. Behind the scenes, there are reportedly multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling for Biden to end his campaign. This suggests a level of coordination and shared sentiment that could lead to a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators working together to ask Biden to consider ending his campaign. The fact that there are already some public expressions of dissent and organized efforts behind the scenes indicates a plausible pathway to the resolution criteria being met before July 20th.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, and (2) A group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
(1) Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat: 
There are two Manifold polls posted, both closing on July 6. One poll asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks them to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot. This will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close. The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.

(2) A group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th: 
Politico reports multiple drafts of letters among House Democrats, with at least one calling on Biden to end his campaign. This resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter or another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out. All five individuals must be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution. Reports of any number of unnamed Democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In ambiguous cases, this market will err towards resolving NO. If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The analysis above explains the considerations for both events and concludes that while the first event is plausible, the second is less likely due to political risks and the requirement for collective, public action.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

This would indeed break the current record of $284.5 million held by the original Deadpool. Additionally, the movie is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million domestically, which would also be the biggest R-rated opening of all-time. Considering these projections and the fact that the movie will likely play at more theaters than the original Deadpool, it seems likely that the movie will break the record. However, it's worth noting that box office performance can be unpredictable, and there's always a chance that the movie might not meet expectations.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Mike Pence being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his current political standing, potential competitors, and the dynamics within the Republican Party. 1. Current Political Standing: As of my last update, Mike Pence has maintained a relatively high profile since leaving office. He has been involved in various initiatives and has continued to engage with the public and the media. However, his popularity and influence within the Republican Party have been overshadowed by other figures, notably former President Donald Trump, who has indicated interest in running for the presidency again. 2. Potential Competitors: The field of potential Republican candidates for the 2024 election is wide and includes several high-profile figures. Besides Donald Trump, other possible contenders such as Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Ted Cruz have significant support within different factions of the party. The competition is likely to be intense, and Pence would need to differentiate himself and garner substantial support from party delegates. 3. Party Dynamics: The Republican Party is currently divided between those who remain loyal to Trump and those looking for a new direction. Pence's association with Trump could be both a blessing and a curse. While it might earn him some support from Trump loyalists, it could also alienate those seeking a fresh start. 4. Pence's Strategy: Pence has attempted to carve out his own identity and build a base of support. He has focused on issues that align with conservative values and has tried to position himself as a leader who can unite different factions of the party. However, it's unclear whether this strategy will be enough to secure the nomination. Considering these factors, while Mike Pence has a path to the nomination, it appears challenging. The competition is fierce, and the dynamics within the party do not clearly favor him. Therefore, the probability of him securing the Republican nomination seems relatively low compared to other contenders.

(b) Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors, including current political trends, the performance of the Greens–EFA in previous elections, and the overall political landscape in Europe. 1. Current Political Trends: The European Green Party and its national member parties have seen a significant surge in popularity in various European countries in recent years, largely due to increased awareness and concern about climate change, environmental issues, and a desire for more progressive policies. This trend suggests a potential for the Greens–EFA to gain more seats. 2. Previous Election Performance: In the 2019 European Parliament elections, the Greens–EFA saw a significant increase in their representation, becoming the fourth-largest group in the European Parliament. This momentum could potentially carry forward into the 2024 elections, depending on how well the group capitalizes on current political sentiments. 3. Political Landscape: The European political landscape is highly dynamic, with shifts in voter preferences and the emergence of new political forces. The Greens–EFA's ability to hold the most seats would depend on their campaign strategies, the appeal of their policies, and how they compare to other political groups in addressing key European issues. 4. Competition: Other political groups, such as the European People's Party (EPP), the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), and the Renew Europe group, are traditionally strong contenders in European Parliament elections. The performance of these groups will directly impact the Greens–EFA's chances of holding the most seats. 5. Tie Scenario: The question allows for a scenario where if two groups are tied for seats, both would be considered as holding the most seats. This slightly increases the probability of a "Yes" resolution since a tie is a more achievable outcome than outright victory. Given these considerations, while the Greens–EFA have momentum and are likely to perform well, the European Parliament elections are highly competitive, and other groups also have strong bases of support. Therefore, the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections is not extremely high but is still a plausible outcome.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors, including regulatory compliance, OpenAI's expansion plans, and potential roadblocks. 1. Regulatory Compliance: The EU has been actively working on regulations for AI, including the AI Act, which aims to provide a framework for the development and deployment of AI systems within the EU. OpenAI would need to ensure that ChatGPT complies with these regulations, which could include requirements for transparency, accountability, and data protection. Given the complexity of these regulations and the need for careful legal and ethical considerations, there's a risk that compliance issues could delay availability. 2. Expansion Plans: OpenAI has shown interest in expanding its services globally, but the pace of this expansion can be influenced by various factors, including market demand, competition, and regulatory environments. If OpenAI prioritizes other markets or faces unexpected challenges in the EU market, this could impact the general availability of ChatGPT. 3. Potential Roadblocks: Beyond regulatory compliance, other potential roadblocks could include technical challenges, public perception, and political considerations. For instance, if there's significant public concern over privacy or the ethical use of AI in certain EU countries, this could lead to political pressure to restrict or delay the service's availability. Considering these factors, while OpenAI has a vested interest in making ChatGPT widely available, including in the EU, the path to general availability is fraught with potential challenges. Their combination in a single film could potentially draw in a massive audience, leveraging the fanbase of both characters. - Previous Box Office Performance: 'Deadpool' (2016) had a remarkable opening, and while 'The Wolverine' (2013) did well, the combined opening of $185,548,391 sets a high but achievable bar for 'Deadpool & Wolverine,' considering the growth in the fanbase and the general increase in box office numbers over time. - Marketing and Competition: The success of 'Deadpool & Wolverine' at the box office would also depend on its marketing campaign and the competitive landscape at the time of its release. A well-executed marketing strategy could significantly boost its opening numbers. question.title: Will Tucker Carlson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Tucker Carlson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Any other candidate being selected will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's break down the key points: 1. Tucker Carlson's Background and Career: Tucker Carlson is a well-known American television host, journalist, and conservative commentator. He has been hosting his own show, Tucker Carlson Tonight, on Fox News since 2016. While he has significant influence in conservative media, his background is more aligned with journalism and commentary rather than traditional politics. 2. Political Experience and Ambition: As of the last available information, Tucker Carlson has not held or sought political office. His influence is significant in the realm of public opinion, but there's a substantial difference between media influence and political candidacy, especially for the highest office in the United States. 3. 2024 Republican Nomination Process: The Republican nomination for the 2024 presidential election will be determined by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. This process involves a series of primaries and caucuses across the United States, culminating in the convention where delegates officially select the party's nominee. 4. Potential Candidates and Competition: The field of potential candidates for the 2024 Republican nomination is broad and includes several individuals with more direct political experience than Tucker Carlson. The competition for the nomination is expected to be fierce, with several high-profile politicians and possibly former President Donald Trump considering a run. 5. Carlson's Public Statements and Actions: There has been no clear indication from Tucker Carlson that he intends to run for the presidency in 2024. His focus appears to remain on his media career, using his platform to influence public opinion and policy discussions rather than seeking elected office. Considering these points, the likelihood of Tucker Carlson being selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is low. While he has a significant following and influence within conservative circles, his lack of direct political experience, the absence of any declared intention to run, and the competitive nature of the nomination process all contribute to this assessment.

question.title: Will Joe Biden still be president by the end of July?
question.body: This market will resolve yes if at 11:59 pm on July 31st 2024 if Joe Biden is still officially president of the United States.

question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Joe Biden having an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes before the end of July 2024, let's break down the relevant information and reasoning: 1. Past Behavior and Frequency of Interviews: The fact that Biden had a 70-minute interview on The Howard Stern Show in April indicates that he is open to longer, in-depth interviews. However, the frequency of such interviews and their duration can vary widely. 2. Nature of Qualifying Interviews: The criteria for what constitutes a qualifying interview are quite specific. It must be in-person, on camera, and at least 45 minutes long. This rules out many common appearances such as press conferences, speeches, rallies, and fundraisers, which are more frequent but do not meet the criteria. 3. Timeframe: The question pertains to a specific timeframe - before the end of July 2024. This is a relatively short period, limiting the number of opportunities for such an interview to occur. 4. Political and Public Engagement Strategy: The strategy for public appearances and interviews can be influenced by political considerations, especially in an election year. The decision to engage in a long, in-depth interview may be strategically made to address specific issues, reach a particular audience, or to counterbalance recent narratives. 5. Availability and Scheduling: The schedules of both the President and potential interviewers (e.g., late-night show hosts, podcasters, journalists) play a significant role. Coordinating such an interview requires aligning the schedules of two busy parties. Given these considerations, while there is a possibility that Biden might engage in a qualifying interview, the specific criteria and the relatively short timeframe make it somewhat challenging. However, considering Biden's past willingness to engage in longer interviews and the strategic importance of such appearances, it's not improbable.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. According to the context provided by Politico, dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort to seal President Joe Biden's nomination sooner than originally planned. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.), has been obtained by POLITICO, which offers the first public signal from Democrats that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy. This suggests that there is already a significant amount of opposition within the Democratic Party to the early nomination plan. Additionally, Rep. Huffman's statement that 'it's a really bad move by the DNC' and that 'somebody thinks it's a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn't work that way' further indicates that there is strong opposition to the plan. The fact that multiple letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES increases the likelihood of the market resolving to YES. Given the information provided, it seems likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.

question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of an athlete winning more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics, let's break down the factors involved: 1. Historical Context: In previous Olympics, it has been common for top tennis players to compete in and win multiple events. For instance, the Williams sisters, Serena and Venus, have both won multiple gold medals in singles and doubles. This suggests that winning more than one medal is achievable for top athletes. 2. Competition Format: Tennis at the Olympics typically includes singles and doubles events for both men and women, as well as a mixed doubles event. This provides multiple opportunities for athletes to win medals. 3. Player Participation: The decision of top players to participate in the Olympics can significantly impact the competition. While some top players may choose not to participate for various reasons (e.g., schedule conflicts, personal reasons), many see the Olympics as a prestigious event and an opportunity to represent their country. 4. Competition Level: The level of competition in Olympic tennis is extremely high, with many of the world's top players participating. However, the ability of a player to win more than one medal often depends on their skill level, physical condition, and the ability to maintain performance over the course of the tournament. 5. Recent Trends: In recent years, there has been a trend of specialization in tennis, with some players focusing more on singles or doubles. However, versatile players who excel in both singles and doubles or in mixed doubles still exist and have the potential to win multiple medals. Considering these factors, the likelihood of an athlete winning more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics seems reasonable. The presence of talented players who can compete at a high level in multiple events increases the chances of this happening.

This spread gives athletes multiple opportunities to win medals. Top tennis players often participate in both singles and doubles events, increasing their chances of winning more than one medal. Historically, it's not uncommon for top tennis players to win multiple medals at the Olympics, but it's also not a guarantee. Given these factors, let's estimate the probability of condition (a) being met as moderately high, around 0.7. Condition (b) - Individual Neutral Athletes win 21 or more gold medals: The term 'Individual Neutral Athletes' likely refers to athletes competing under the Olympic flag or a neutral designation due to various reasons such as sanctions against their home country. The number of gold medals won by such athletes can vary greatly depending on the number of athletes competing under the neutral designation, the sports and events they participate in, and the level of competition. However, winning 21 or more gold medals would require a significant presence and success across multiple sports and events, which seems unlikely given the usual distribution of Olympic medals. Given these considerations, the probability of condition (b) being met seems relatively low, around 0.2. Combining the probabilities of both independent conditions being met requires multiplying the probabilities of each condition: 0.7 (condition a) * 0.2 (condition b) = 0.14. Therefore, the probability that both conditions (a and b) will occur at the 2024 Paris Olympics is estimated to be 0.14.

question.title: Will a swimmer win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a swimmer winning the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics, let's consider several factors: 1. Historical Performance: Historically, swimmers have performed exceptionally well at the Olympics. The sport offers a wide range of events, which increases the potential for athletes to win multiple medals. Notable swimmers like Michael Phelps have set records for the most gold medals won by an individual in Olympic history, demonstrating the potential for high medal counts in swimming. 2. Competition Format: Swimming competitions at the Olympics are structured in a way that allows top athletes to compete in multiple events. This is unlike some other sports where athletes or teams might be limited to competing in a single event. The ability to participate in multiple races (e.g., different strokes and distances) increases a swimmer's chances of accumulating medals. 3. Global Talent Pool: The global talent pool in swimming is deep, but it's also a sport where a few exceptional athletes can dominate multiple events. This concentration of talent can lead to a scenario where one swimmer accumulates a significant number of gold medals. 4. Comparative Advantage in Medal Accumulation: Compared to other sports, swimming has a relatively high number of events. This increases the chances for a swimmer to win more medals compared to athletes in sports with fewer events. 5. Current Trends and Athlete Performance: Without specific data on the current crop of athletes leading up to the 2024 Olympics, it's difficult to pinpoint who might be the top contenders. However, the trend of swimmers performing well and winning multiple medals is expected to continue. Considering these factors, it seems reasonable to conclude that a swimmer has a good chance of winning the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics, given the sport's history, the structure of the competitions, and the potential for individual athletes to dominate multiple events.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early, let's break down the key points from the provided context and analyze them step by step. 1. Internal Party Dissent: The context indicates there is a significant level of dissent within the Democratic Party regarding the plan to nominate President Biden early. This dissent suggests that there is a faction within the party that is not aligned with the party leadership's strategy, which could lead to public displays of opposition. 2. Organized Effort: The mention of "dozens of House Democrats" organizing a plan to speak out against the early nomination indicates a level of coordination and intent among party members. This organized effort increases the likelihood of a public letter being drafted and signed. 3. Drafted Letter: The existence of a drafted letter, as mentioned, is a tangible step towards public opposition. The fact that it has been circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) provides evidence of concrete actions being taken by those opposed to the early nomination plan. 4. Public Signal: The letter represents the "first public signal" from Democrats that there is significant unrest regarding President Biden's candidacy. This willingness to make the dissent public could encourage others to join, potentially reaching the threshold of 20 signatures. 5. Resolution Criteria: The market resolves to YES if a public letter (or multiple letters) opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before the market close. This specific, measurable criterion makes it easier to assess the probability based on the actions and intentions of the individuals involved. Considering these points, the key factors influencing the probability are the level of dissent, the organized effort among Democrats, the existence of a drafted letter, and the willingness to make the dissent public. Given the context, it seems there is a substantial likelihood of the criteria being met, as there is both intent and action among the party members opposed to the early nomination plan.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, let's consider the factors that could lead to a brokered convention in the Democratic Party for the 2024 presidential election. 1. Number of Candidates: A brokered convention is more likely when there are multiple strong candidates who split the vote, preventing any one candidate from achieving a majority (more than 50% of the delegates) in the first round of voting. As of my last update, the Democratic field is relatively narrow compared to the 2020 election cycle, which saw a historically large number of candidates. 2. Delegate Allocation Rules: The Democratic Party allocates delegates proportionally, which means candidates can accumulate delegates even if they don't win a majority in a particular state or district. However, the party also has rules requiring candidates to meet a minimum threshold of support (usually 15%) to be eligible for delegates. This can sometimes help narrow the field by denying delegates to weaker candidates. 3. Party Unity and Brokerage: The term "brokered convention" implies a scenario where party leaders or influential figures negotiate behind the scenes to coalesce support around a candidate. The likelihood of such negotiations succeeding depends on the party's internal dynamics and the willingness of candidates to compromise or withdraw. 4. Recent Trends and Polling: As of my last update, polling in the Democratic primary has shown a couple of front-runners with significant leads over the rest of the field. However, the landscape can change rapidly due to factors like debate performances, endorsements, and unforeseen events. Considering these factors, the current landscape suggests that while a brokered convention is possible, it seems less likely than a straightforward nomination process. The field is not as crowded as in previous cycles, and proportional delegate allocation can help the leading candidates accumulate delegates more efficiently. However, the dynamics of the primary can shift rapidly, and unforeseen developments could still lead to a scenario where no candidate achieves a majority on the first ballot.

(a) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early: This resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

(b) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024: This resolves as YES if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Ted Cruz being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors, including his past performance in elections, his popularity within the Republican Party, the potential field of candidates, and the current political climate. Ted Cruz has a history of running for president, having been a candidate in the 2016 Republican primary. He won several primaries and caucuses, ultimately finishing second to Donald Trump. This experience could be beneficial if he decides to run again, as he has built a network of supporters and donors. However, Cruz's popularity within the Republican Party is a mixed bag. While he has a strong following among some conservative voters, others view him as too divisive or too focused on his own ambitions. His actions during the 2020 presidential election, particularly his role in objecting to the certification of Joe Biden's victory, have also been controversial. The field of potential candidates for the 2024 Republican nomination is likely to be crowded, with several high-profile figures already mentioned as possible contenders. These include Donald Trump, Mike Pence, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, among others. Cruz will face stiff competition from these candidates, many of whom have strong followings and significant fundraising abilities. The current political climate also plays a role in Cruz's chances. The Republican Party is still grappling with the aftermath of the 2020 election and the January 6th insurrection. Cruz's actions during this time have been criticized by some, which could hurt his standing with moderate voters. Given these factors, I estimate that Ted Cruz has a relatively low chance of being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While he has a dedicated following and significant experience, the field of candidates is likely to be crowded, and his divisive reputation may hurt his ability to attract broader support.

It would likely be a strategic decision made with considerable input from party leaders, and there has been no indication of such discussions happening on a scale that would suggest this outcome. 5. Market and Public Perception: Prediction markets and public opinion can sometimes provide insight into potential political outcomes. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of a specific and rare event occurring - the invocation of Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare President Biden incapacitated. This section allows the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) to declare the President unable to discharge his duties, making the Vice President the Acting President. Several factors make this event unlikely: 1. Historical Precedent: The 25th Amendment has been invoked a few times, but primarily under Section 3, where the President voluntarily transfers power to the Vice President due to a temporary inability to serve (e.g., during medical procedures). Invocation under Section 4, without the President's consent, is unprecedented and represents a significant political and constitutional step that would likely be taken only in extreme circumstances. 2. Political Considerations: Such an action would have profound political implications and repercussions. It would require significant bipartisan agreement or a substantial shift in political will among the President's own party members, as well as independent confirmation of the President's inability to serve. Given the polarized nature of U.S. politics, achieving the necessary consensus would be challenging. 3. Medical and Public Evidence: There would need to be clear, publicly evident reasons for the President's incapacitation that would justify such a drastic measure. While President Biden's health has been a subject of public discussion, there has been no indication of an inability to discharge his duties that would warrant invocation of the 25th Amendment. 4. Procedural Hurdles: The process involves more than just a simple declaration. It requires written declaration by the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet, followed by a two-thirds vote in both the House and Senate if contested by the President. This is a high bar to clear, especially considering the political divisions in Congress. Given these considerations, the likelihood of President Biden being declared incapacitated under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment before August 2024 is very low.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The analysis is based on Christie's past political experience, the competitive landscape of the Republican primaries, mixed public perception, and the importance of fundraising and campaign infrastructure.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (b) Chris Christie is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination.

(b) Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

This resolves as Yes if Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the current political landscape and the lack of strong indicators supporting either event, it is reasonable to conclude that the probability of both Joe Biden declining the Democratic nomination and Chris Christie securing the Republican nomination is low.

question.title: Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for the **Deadpool & Wolverine** reported by Boxofficemojo on the [movie's page](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6263850/?ref_=bo_se_r_1) is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering the growth of the box office, the popularity of the characters involved, and the potential for a well-received film, it seems plausible that 'Deadpool & Wolverine' would outperform the combined openings of the individual films.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we must consider the likelihood of a specific and rare event occurring: the invocation of Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare President Biden incapacitated. This section allows the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or another relevant body) to declare the President unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office, making the Vice President the Acting President. Several factors suggest this event is unlikely: 1. Historical Precedent: The 25th Amendment has been invoked a few times since its ratification in 1967, but Section 4 specifically has never been used. The lack of precedent suggests a high threshold for its invocation. 2. Political Implications: Declaring the President incapacitated under Section 4 is a politically charged decision that would likely face significant opposition and could have substantial political repercussions. It's not a step that would be taken lightly. 3. Definition of Incapacity: The amendment leaves the definition of 'unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office' somewhat vague. This ambiguity could lead to disagreements over whether the President's condition warrants such action. 4. Procedural Hurdles: The process requires the concurrence of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet, which could be difficult to achieve, especially in a politically divided environment. 5. Public Perception and Support: The President enjoys a certain level of public support and goodwill. Invoking Section 4 without clear and compelling evidence of incapacitation could be seen as a political coup, potentially leading to public backlash. Given these considerations, the likelihood of President Biden being declared incapacitated under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment before August 2024 appears low.

(b) Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter, and Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The combined probability of Nikki Haley being the Republican nominee and President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is low due to the speculative nature of both events and the seriousness and rarity of invoking the 25th Amendment.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce that he is both dropping out and resigning from the presidency before the end of July?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Joe Biden announces both that he is no longer running for re-election and that he will be resigning and not completing his current term. These announcements before the end of July 2024 in Pacific Time, but he does not have to have formally resigned and be out of office before the end of July. An announcement of his intention to do so is sufficient to resolve this market.

Otherwise, this market resolves NO on August 1st.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Joe Biden announcing that he is both dropping out of the presidential race and resigning from the presidency before the end of July, we need to consider several factors. Firstly, it's essential to note that such an announcement would be unprecedented in U.S. history, indicating a significant departure from the norm. Secondly, Joe Biden has shown no public indication of intending to drop out or resign. His campaign for re-election is ongoing, and there have been no credible reports or leaks suggesting he plans to step down. Moreover, the act of resigning from the presidency is a drastic measure that would typically be reserved for extreme circumstances, such as severe health issues or significant scandals. While Biden has faced challenges and criticisms, there's no current indication that these would lead to his resignation. Lastly, the timing of such an announcement before the end of July seems arbitrary without a specific reason or event that would trigger it. Political decisions of this magnitude are usually the result of careful planning and strategic timing, not arbitrary deadlines. Given these considerations, the likelihood of Joe Biden making such an announcement seems extremely low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump being charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Ongoing Investigation: The question pertains to an ongoing investigation, The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al, which suggests that there is already a legal framework within which charges could be brought. This indicates a higher likelihood of action being taken compared to if there were no investigation. 2. Previous Actions by Trump: Donald Trump has been known to make public statements about various investigations and legal proceedings he is involved in, which could potentially be interpreted as witness tampering if they are deemed to influence or intimidate witnesses. Given his past behavior, it's plausible he could act similarly in this case. 3. Legal Definitions and Thresholds: Witness tampering charges require specific legal thresholds to be met, including intent to influence or intimidate a witness. The determination of whether Trump's actions meet these criteria would depend on the specifics of his statements and the context in which they are made. 4. Prosecutorial Discretion: The decision to charge Trump with witness tampering would ultimately rest with the prosecutors handling the case. This decision would be influenced by their assessment of the evidence, the potential impact on the broader case, and possibly political considerations. 5. Timeline: The question specifies a deadline of June 1, 2024. Given the pace at which legal proceedings often move, it's possible that charges could be brought within this timeframe if there is sufficient evidence and will to do so. However, legal processes can be slow and unpredictable. Considering these factors, it seems there is a plausible scenario in which Trump could be charged with witness tampering, especially given his past behavior and the existence of an ongoing investigation. However, the decision to bring charges would depend heavily on specific actions by Trump and the strategic decisions of prosecutors, which introduces a significant element of uncertainty.

question.title: Will Iceland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Iceland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If not, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Iceland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors including Iceland's past performance in Eurovision, the competition format, and the subjective nature of the contest's voting system. Iceland has had varied success in Eurovision. While they have qualified for the Grand Final several times, their participation has not always led to qualification. The country's most successful entries have been those that manage to stand out either through unique performances, catchy songs, or effective staging. The Eurovision Semi-finals feature a large number of countries competing for a limited number of spots in the Grand Final. The qualification process involves a combination of jury and public voting, making the outcome somewhat unpredictable. However, countries that manage to appeal to both the juries and the public tend to have a higher chance of qualifying. Given that the question specifically asks about qualification and not about winning, we should consider that a few countries in each Semi-final are usually clear frontrunners for qualification based on pre-contest hype and rehearsals. However, surprises can and do occur due to the live nature of the performances and the voting dynamics. Without specific details about Iceland's entry for 2024, such as the artist, song, and staging plans, we can only rely on historical data and the general dynamics of the contest. Historically, Iceland has a decent qualification rate but is not among the countries that consistently qualify. Considering these factors, a cautious approach is to assume that Iceland has a somewhat better than even chance of qualifying, given their past performances and the unpredictable nature of the contest. However, without knowing the specifics of their 2024 entry, it's hard to assign a very high probability.

question.title: Will Ireland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ireland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Ireland does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Ireland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, let's consider several factors that could influence their chances: 1. Historical Performance: Ireland has a rich history in Eurovision, having won the contest a record seven times. However, their performance has been less consistent in recent years. Since the introduction of the semi-final format in 2004, Ireland has qualified for the final roughly half the time. This suggests that while they have the potential to do well, qualification is far from guaranteed. 2. Song and Artist Quality: The quality of the song and the performing artist can significantly impact a country's chances. Without knowing who will represent Ireland in 2024 and what their song will be, it's difficult to assess this factor accurately. However, Ireland has shown the ability to select competitive entries in the past. 3. Voting Patterns: Eurovision voting can be influenced by geopolitical factors, with countries often voting for their neighbors or countries with cultural ties. Ireland might benefit from votes from the UK and possibly other English-speaking or Western European countries, but this is not a strong guarantee of qualification. 4. Competition: The level of competition in the semi-finals can vary significantly from year to year. Some years see a concentration of strong entries in one semi-final, making it harder for others to qualify. Without knowing the lineup for the semi-finals, it's challenging to assess how tough the competition will be for Ireland. 5. Performance on the Night: The live performance, including staging, vocals, and overall presentation, can greatly impact the outcome. A memorable and well-executed performance can boost a country's chances of qualifying. Considering these factors, it's clear that while Ireland has potential, the outcome is far from certain. Their historical performance suggests a roughly 50% qualification rate in the semi-final era, but without knowing the specifics of their entry, the competition, and how voting patterns will play out, it's hard to deviate significantly from this baseline. Given the information available, a cautious approach would be to estimate Ireland's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final as being around the historical average, acknowledging that there are many variables that could influence the outcome.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Iceland and Ireland participate in their respective Semi-finals and are officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. According to the context provided, dozens of House Democrats are already organizing a plan to speak out against this effort, and a drafted letter has been circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman. This suggests that there is already significant opposition to the plan within the Democratic Party. Additionally, the fact that multiple letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would be sufficient to resolve the market to YES increases the likelihood of a positive outcome. However, it's also possible that some Democrats may not want to publicly oppose the plan, especially if they think it will ultimately pass. Therefore, while there is a good chance that at least 20 Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan, it's not a certainty.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As explained, considering polarization, the appeal of a generic Democrat, and the specifics of the Manifold respondents.

The decision often reflects a balance of political strategy, personal chemistry with the nominee, and the candidate's own willingness to take the role. Given these considerations, while Kelly and Shapiro are reportedly the favorites, predicting political decisions with certainty is challenging. The decision could hinge on factors not publicly known, such as personal chemistry or strategic considerations that aren't immediately apparent. Therefore, based on the information provided and the inherent unpredictability of political decisions, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that Kamala Harris chooses either Kelly or Shapiro, given their reported status as favorites. question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the past behavior, specific criteria, previous interviews, and the time frame, there is a reasonable likelihood of Joe Biden participating in an interview that meets the specified conditions.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to Donald Trump would require a clear determination of his involvement in insurrection or rebellion, a process fraught with legal and political hurdles, making it unlikely to conclude by the specified date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes before the end of July 2024, and (2) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
(1) Joe Biden must appear in an in-person interview for at least 45 minutes before the end of July 2024. This includes appearances on podcasts or late night shows, or interviews edited into shows like 60 minutes, but not press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. There must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this condition is not met.

(2) Donald Trump must be officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. This must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, this condition is not met.

Both conditions must be met for the question to resolve as YES.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to break it down into its two components and assess the likelihood of each event occurring. 1. Joe Biden having an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes before the end of July 2024: It's common for sitting presidents and high-profile political figures to engage in interviews and public appearances. Given the significance of the 2024 election and the ongoing political discourse, it's reasonable to expect that Joe Biden will participate in various interviews and media engagements. However, the specific requirement of a 45+ minute in-person interview on camera is somewhat more particular. While not a certainty, it's plausible that such an opportunity will arise, especially considering the numerous late-night shows, podcasts, and in-depth interview formats available. The probability of this event occurring seems relatively high, given the typical media engagement strategies of political figures. 2. Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This condition is more complex and involves legal and political considerations. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, has rarely been invoked and its application is subject to legal interpretation and challenge. For Donald Trump to be removed or blocked under this clause, there would need to be significant legal action or a definitive court ruling, which is difficult to predict. The process would likely involve substantial legal battles and could extend beyond the specified deadline of July 15, 2024. Given the uncertainties of the legal process and the rarity of the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, this event seems less likely than the first condition. Considering both conditions must be met for the question to resolve as YES, we need to multiply the probabilities of each event occurring. While I haven't assigned specific probabilities in the reasoning, based on the analysis: - The first condition seems relatively plausible, given common practices in political media engagement. - The second condition is more improbable due to the legal complexities and the rare application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. Given these considerations, a generous estimate for the combined probability might lean towards the lower end of the spectrum, reflecting the complexity and specificity of both conditions needing to be met.

Both countries need to select entries that are likely to appeal to both the jury and the public. The competition format, including the semi-final allocation draw and the voting system (a combination of jury and public voting), plays a crucial role. Given these considerations, predicting qualification with certainty is challenging without knowing the specific entries for 2024. However, we can make a general assessment based on past performance and the assumption that both countries will strive to select competitive entries. Both Georgia and Malta have the potential to qualify, but given the competitive nature of the contest and their recent track records, it's not a guarantee for either country.
